text: One phenomenon we've seen when teams are building things really quickly with AI is that the more AI-generated or assisted they are, the more generic they tend to turn out. Put yourself in a situation where you can slow down and do some hard thinking, some deep thinking about what's actually going to make your product unique. Going fast can actually slow you down in the long run.
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: Lenny asks why teams shouldn't just build something quickly and launch it to learn, rather than spending time on strategic planning. John explains a counterintuitive problem with AI-assisted development: while AI tools allow teams to build faster than ever, they often produce generic solutions because LLMs are trained on existing data. He argues that without taking time to think deeply about differentiation upfront, teams may waste time building something that looks polished but fails to stand out in the market.
vocabulary_highlights: generic they tend to turn out
text_ko: 인공지능(AI)을 써서 아주 빠르게 무언가를 만드는 팀들을 보면 한 가지 공통된 현상이 있어요. AI가 많이 생성하거나 보조할수록 결과물이 더 평범해지는 경향이 있더라고요. 일부러 속도를 늦추고 제품이 진짜로 무엇으로 차별화될지 깊게 고민할 수 있는 상황을 만들어 보세요. 단기적으로 빨리 가는 것이 좋아 보여도, 장기적으로는 오히려 발목을 잡아서 더 느리게 만들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们发现一个现象，就是团队用AI快速开发产品的时候，AI生成或辅助得越多，做出来的东西就越千篇一律。你得让自己慢下来，好好想想，深入思考一下到底什么能让你的产品与众不同。一味求快，长远来看反而会拖慢你的步伐。
text_es: Un fenómeno que hemos notado cuando los equipos están desarrollando cosas súper rápido con IA es que entre más generada o asistida por IA sea, más genérica tiende a salir. Ponte en una situación donde puedas bajar el ritmo y hacer un pensamiento profundo, una reflexión seria sobre qué es lo que realmente va a hacer único tu producto. Ir muy rápido en realidad te puede hacer más lento a largo plazo.
key_sentence: AI-generated products tend to be generic; slow down for hard thinking.

text: We would have a conversation with founders, you're saying like, 'Gosh, I'm almost embarrassed to ask this question, but who exactly is your target customer?' And three co-founders have three different answers.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Jake introduces a common problem they've observed when working with startup founders. Despite seeming like basic questions, fundamental aspects of a business strategy are often unclear or misaligned among team members. This example illustrates why the Foundation Sprint process is necessary - even successful, intelligent founders frequently lack alignment on core business questions that seem obvious but are actually quite complex to define precisely.
text_ko: 창업자들과 얘기할 때면, "정말 이런 질문 드리기가 좀 민망한데요, 정확히 누가 당신들의 타깃 고객(target customer)이에요?"라고 물어보곤 해요. 그런데 공동창업자들(co-founders) 세 명이 저마다 다른 대답을 해요.
text_zh: 我们跟创始人聊天的时候，会说："不好意思啊，这个问题可能有点尴尬，但你们的目标客户到底是谁？"结果三个联合创始人给出三个完全不同的答案。
text_es: Teníamos conversaciones with fundadores donde les decíamos algo como: "Oye, casi me da pena preguntar esto, pero ¿quién es exactamente tu cliente objetivo?" Y resulta que los tres cofundadores te dan tres respuestas completamente diferentes.
key_sentence: Founders often feel almost embarrassed to ask who exactly is the target customer.

text: After these hundreds of teams that we've worked with, we've seen that there's one failure mode, which is they don't know what that set of basics are. Then there's this other failure mode where they never test it.
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: John identifies two common patterns of failure they've observed across hundreds of startup teams they've worked with at Google Ventures and Character Capital. The first failure mode occurs when teams haven't clearly defined fundamental aspects like target customer and competitive differentiation. The second happens when teams think they know these basics but never validate their assumptions with real customers, leading to building products that don't achieve product-market fit.
text_ko: 우리가 함께 일해온 수백 개의 팀을 보면, 한 가지 실패 유형(failure mode)이 있어요 — 팀들이 어떤 기본이 필요한지 모른다는 거예요. 또 다른 실패 유형은 그 기본을 아예 검증하지 않는다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们跟几百个团队合作下来，发现有两个常见的坑：一个是他们根本不知道什么是基础要素，另一个是知道了但从来不去验证测试。
text_es: Después de trabajar con cientos de equipos, hemos visto que hay un tipo de fallo, que es cuando no saben cuáles son esos fundamentos básicos. Y luego está este otro tipo de fallo donde nunca lo ponen a prueba.
key_sentence: One failure mode is not knowing the set of basics; another is to never test it.

text: The very beginning of your project, we recommend this kind of crazy idea that you clear your calendar. So the core team come together for 10 hours roughly and go through a sequence of activities so that we can make all of the key decisions together.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Lenny asks Jake to explain how the Foundation Sprint process works. Jake describes the unconventional but essential first step: dedicating focused, uninterrupted time for strategic alignment. The Foundation Sprint requires the core leadership team (co-founders, heads of product, engineering, design, and marketing) to commit 10 hours over two days to work through structured activities that establish the fundamental strategy and hypothesis for their startup or product.
text_ko: 프로젝트 초반에는 일정을 전부 비워두는 다소 과감한 방법을 추천해요. 핵심 팀(core team)이 한자리에 모여 대략 10시간 정도 집중해서 일련의 활동(sequence of activities)을 진행하면서 모든 주요 의사결정을 함께 내리는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 在项目刚开始的时候，我们建议你们来个疯狂的想法——把日程全部清空。让核心团队聚在一起大概10个小时，一起做一系列的活动，这样我们就能把所有关键决策都敲定了。
text_es: Al mero inicio de tu proyecto, te recomendamos esta idea medio loca de que liberes tu agenda. Así el equipo principal se junta como unas 10 horas y pasa por una serie de actividades para que podamos tomar todas las decisiones clave juntos.
key_sentence: Clear your calendar for 10 hours to make key decisions together.

text: We're going to use the advantages we have. We're going to use our insight, we're going to use our motivation, we're going to use our special capabilities. These are things, again, people are aware of these things, they're in tune to it, but we want to get super, super specific.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Jake explains the differentiation phase of the Foundation Sprint, which focuses on identifying what sets a startup apart from competitors. Rather than competing on generic factors like price or speed, successful startups need to leverage their unique advantages - special insights about the market, personal motivation for solving the problem, or distinctive capabilities the team possesses. The key is making these advantages explicit and specific rather than keeping them as vague assumptions.
text_ko: 우리가 가진 장점들을 활용할 거예요. 통찰력도 활용하고, 동기도 활용하고, 우리만의 특별한 역량도 활용할 거예요. 이런 건 다들 알고 공감하는 부분이지만, 저희는 여기서 훨씬 더 구체적으로 들어가려고 해요. 정말 정말 구체적으로요.
text_zh: 我们要把自己的优势都用上。我们的洞察力要用上，我们的动力要用上，还有我们的特殊能力也要用上。这些东西大家其实都知道，也都有感觉，但是我们要做得非常非常具体。
text_es: Vamos a aprovechar las ventajas que tenemos. Vamos a usar nuestra visión estratégica, vamos a usar nuestra motivación, vamos a usar nuestras capacidades especiales. Estas son cosas que, bueno, la gente ya las conoce, ya están al tanto, pero queremos ser súper, súper específicos.
key_sentence: Get super, super specific about your special capabilities; leverage your advantages.

text: While you're outsourcing that prototyping work, you don't outsource the thinking. You don't kind of skip over the part where you think about, 'Well, what is the actual copy on the website? How do I actually describe what the product is, how it's differentiated?'
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: John discusses how AI tools are changing the prototyping process in design sprints. While AI can rapidly generate realistic-looking prototypes and marketing materials, he warns against letting AI handle the strategic thinking behind those outputs. Teams must still do the hard work of defining their unique value proposition, target messaging, and differentiation strategy before using AI to execute and build prototypes based on that strategic foundation.
text_ko: 그 프로토타이핑(prototyping) 작업을 아웃소싱(outsourcing)으로 맡기더라도, 아이디어나 전략 같은 생각하는 부분까지는 아웃소싱할 수는 없어요. '웹사이트에 실제로 들어갈 카피는 뭘로 할까? 제품을 어떻게 설명하고, 어떤 점에서 차별화되는지 어떻게 표현할까?' 같은 고민은 건너뛰면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 虽然你可以把原型制作(prototyping)外包出去，但是思考这一块儿你可不能外包。你不能跳过那些需要动脑子的环节，比如说"网站上到底写什么文案？我怎么描述这个产品？它的差异化在哪儿？"这些问题你都得自己想清楚。
text_es: Aunque subcontratas el trabajo de prototipos, no subcontratas el pensamiento. No puedes saltarte la parte donde te pones a pensar: "Bueno, ¿cuál va a ser el copy real del sitio web? ¿Cómo describo realmente qué es el producto y cómo se diferencia?"
key_sentence: Don't outsource the thinking; never skip over how it's differentiated.
